issues.text: The first question which falls to be considered in this appeal is whether the appellant is a successor interest of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls to be considered in this appeal is whether the appellant is a successor interest of the Company. arguments.claim: Under s.25FF, on transfer of undertaking, workmen entitled only to notice and compensation as if retrenched from transferor; no claim for re-employment against transferee.

anchor.surface_text: That takes us to the question as to what would be the nature of the appellants liability to the employees of the Company. Before s. 25-FF was introduced in the Act in 1956, this question considered by industrial adjudication

arguments.claim: Pre-s.25FF, industrial adjudication resolved re-employment claims case-by-case on fair play/social justice, weighing reasons for refusal.

anchor.surface_text: on general considerations of fair play and social justice. In all cases where the employees of the transferor concern claimed re-employment at the hands of the transferee concern, industrial adjudication first enquired into the question

arguments.claim: s.25FF enacted against background of industrial adjudication; amended post-Hariprasad to ensure compensation on transfer despite not being 'retrenchment'.

anchor.surface_text: It was in the background of this broad position which had evolved out of industrial adjudications that the Legislature enacted s. 25-FF on September 4,1956.

arguments.claim: In Hariprasad, retrenchment does not include termination on closure/transfer; s.25FF uses 'as if retrenched' fiction for compensation measure only.

arguments.claim: s.25-H does not apply as transfer termination not retrenchment; confirmed by Hariprasad and Hatisingh.

anchor.surface_text: This argument proceeds on the assumption that the case of termination of service resulting from the transfer of ownership or management of an undertaking to which s. 25-FF applies is a case of retrenchment properly so-called.

arguments.claim: Fair play/social justice does not justify re-employment after compensation under s.25FF; would give double benefit anomalous with purpose of retrenchment compensation (tide over unemployment).

arguments.claim: Retrenchment compensation purpose is partial protection to tide over unemployment, per Indian Hume Pipe.

anchor.surface_text: the industrial principle underlying the award of retrenchment compensation is, as observed by this Court in the case of The Indian Hume Pipe Co. Ltd. v. The Workmen, to give partial protection

holdings.text: The question as to whether a purchaser of an industrial concern can be held to be a successor-in-interest of the vendor will have to be decided on a consideration of several relevant facts including whether the whole business was purchased, if it was a going concern, carried on at same place without substantial break, same/similar business, goodwill purchased, etc.; no single factor decisive; substance over form.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether a purchaser of an industrial concern can be held to be a successor-in-interest of the vendor will have to be decided on a consideration of several relevant facts. Did the purchaser purchase the whole of the business ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizes prior industrial adjudication and distinguishes precedents like Ramjilal and Antony D'Souza; lists illustrative factors; emphasizes evaluation of all relevant facts without inflexible rules.

holdings.text: The appellant is a successor-in-interest of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are inclined to take the view that having regard to all the relevant facts in this case, the Tribunal was right in law in coming to the conclusion that the appellant is a successor in-interest of the Company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test to facts: excluded assets minor, business same place without appreciable break, formed by local growers to continue operations; substance prevails over form.

holdings.text: Under s.25FF, on transfer of undertaking, workmen entitled to notice and compensation in accordance with s.25F as if retrenched; this is the only relief against transferor; no claim for re-employment against transferee unless proviso applies.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, reading section 25-FF as a whole. it does appear that unless the transfer falls under the proviso, the employees of the transferred concern are entitled to claim compensation against the transferor and they cannot make any claim for reemployment against the transferee of the undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/purposive interpretation post-Hariprasad amendment; 'as if retrenched' fiction for compensation measure only; scheme excludes re-employment to avoid double benefit; consistent with pre-1956 adjudication.

holdings.text: s.25H does not apply to termination of service on transfer of undertaking under s.25FF, as such termination is not retrenchment.

anchor.surface_text: This argument proceeds on the assumption that the case of termination of service resulting from the transfer of ownership or management of an undertaking to which s. 25-FF applies is a case of retrenchment properly so-called.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Hariprasad (retrenchment excludes transfer/closure); s.25FF 'as if' distinguishes; confirmed in Hatisingh; s.25F referenced only for compensation quantum.

holdings.text: Principles of fair play and social justice do not justify re-employment claim against transferee after compensation under s.25FF, as it would confer anomalous double benefit inconsistent with purpose of retrenchment compensation (to tide over unemployment).

anchor.surface_text: Once we reach the conclusion that in the case of a transfer of any undertaking the Legislature has by s. 25-FF provided for payment of compensation to the employees on the clear and distinct basis that their services have been terminated by such transfer,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-s.25FF, statutory scheme supersedes pre-statutory equity; compensation acknowledges termination; re-employment would unfair to parties; purpose per Indian Hume Pipe.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's award directing re-employment, continuity of service and back wages is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed and the award is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from holdings on s.25FF scope excluding re-employment relief.
